title: 104_hr1668
content: The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 establishes a program to improve the prevention, detection, and control of fraud and abuse under the Medicare program. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will pay a portion of any civil monetary penalty assessed under Medicare to individuals providing information that led to the penalty. SEC. 3 of the Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 adds a new section for soliciting information on fraud and abuse related to Medicare claims and benefit forms. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 includes a new section (Sec. 1893) that solicits information on fraud and abuse in Medicare claims and benefit forms. It also establishes a toll-free number for reporting such information. Effective January 1, 1996, this amendment applies to items and services provided under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Additionally, there is an increase in penalties outlined in SEC. 4. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 increases civil and criminal penalties under the Social Security Act. Civil penalties are raised from $2,000 to $4,000 and from $15,000 to $30,000. Criminal penalties are increased from $25,000 to $50,000 and from $10,000 to $20,000. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 increases civil and criminal penalties under the Social Security Act. Civil penalties are raised to $4,000 and $30,000, while criminal penalties are increased to $50,000 and $20,000. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 increases civil and criminal penalties under the Social Security Act. Civil penalties are raised to $4,000 and $30,000, while criminal penalties are increased to $50,000 and $20,000. Amendments include raising the amounts for unassigned claims, distribution of medical necessity forms, failure to include diagnosis codes, and intermediate sanctions for providers of clinical diagnostic laboratory tests. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 increases penalties under the Social Security Act. Civil penalties are raised to $4,000 and $30,000, while criminal penalties are increased to $50,000 and $20,000. Amendments include raising amounts for various violations related to Medicare secondary payer provisions. The Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act of 1995 increases penalties under the Social Security Act, including raising civil penalties to $4,000 and $30,000, and criminal penalties to $50,000 and $20,000. Various violations related to Medicare secondary payer provisions are also amended, with increased penalties for improper billing by hospitals and violations of anti-dumping restrictions. Section 1876(i)(6)(B)(i) of the Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act is amended to increase penalties: from $25,000 to $50,000, $100,000 to $200,000, and $15,000 to $30,000. Referrals by physicians with ownership interests also face higher penalties: from $15,000 to $30,000 for improper claims and from $100,000 to $200,000 for circumvention schemes. Section 1877(g)(5) of the Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act is amended to increase penalties for failure to report information from $10,000 to $20,000. Section 1882 of the Act is also amended to raise penalties for Medicare supplemental policies, including issuance of policies without standards and misrepresentations of policies. The penalties for violations of various standards under the Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act are increased from $25,000 to $50,000 in certain sections of the Act. This includes violations related to benefits, guaranteed renewability, loss ratio, and pre-existing conditions. Penalties for violations of standards under the Medicare Fraud and Abuse Control Act are increased in certain sections, such as pre-existing condition standards and home health participation standards. The penalties are raised from $5,000 to $10,000, $25,000 to $50,000, $2,000 to $4,000, and $10,000 to $20,000. The amendments increase penalties from $10,000 to $20,000 for acts occurring after January 1, 1996.
